title: Ticket #35: condor_schedd: use hardlinks for executables in SPOOL whenever possibl
description:
An idea for reducing disk space use in the SPOOL: whenever the condor_schedd is about to copy a binary/initial checkpoint/ickpt into SPOOL, it should look for an identical binary owned by the same user. If such a binary exists, simply hardlink the existing one to the new one’s name.

Advantages: Saves disk space no matter how the jobs arrive, so long as they share a binary. Can save space on jobs submitted via Condor-C.

Disadvantages: Starting with 6.9.1, the default for copy_to_spool FALSE, so the local submission benefit is minimal. This is new functionality, and would necessitate someone tracking file identities (probably using a hashing algorithm). Will this tracking information be held by the schedd and lost on restart? That would be safe, but would make it less effective. If it’s stored on disk, where? Perhaps squeezed into the ickpt’s filename?

A tempting proposal, especially since it will benefit Condor-C users. We have a number of Condor-C users who are basically submitting the same binary or small number of binaries over and over again, so this would help them.
